Award.AwardTitle: IDBR: TYPE A: Highly Efficient and Rapid Viral Aerosol Detection System (HERVADS)
Award.AbstractNarration:
An award is made to the University of Florida to develop a bioaerosol instrument whose purpose is to enable highly efficient and rapid detection of airborne viruses. Existing bioaerosol sampling systems are designed for bacterial aerosol collection/detection, which are very ineffective for capturing viral aerosols because viruses are much smaller than bacteria. In addition, conventional detection methods for viruses are time consuming and therefore do not allow determination in field investigation. The novel Highly Efficient and Rapid Viral Aerosol Detection System (HERVADS) utilizes cooling and mixing methods to enable particle size amplification so that the nanosized viruses can be efficiently collected from air (>90% of the new device compared to 5-10% of the existing device). Integrated with a paper-based microfluidic device with selective and sensitive immunoassay, the instrument allows detection of sampled viruses in minutes, orders of magnitude faster than the current method (in days), thus enabling its uses in the field. Incorporation of electrostatic mechanism into the system further enables detection of viral aerosols even in low concentration. By working closely with an industrial partner, the research team will have frequent and in-time feedbacks that allow incorporation of critical features for successful commercial development in the future. The University of Florida?s Office of Technology Licensing will also assist the research team in feasibility assessment, dissemination and outreach.

Successful development and implementation of the novel HERVADS will have significant societal impacts. The HERVADS will impact environmental field studies, enabling the sampling of viruses of environmental and agricultural importance and furthering our basic understanding of the natural diversity of viruses associated with a variety of environmental niches. The HERVADS can also be used to help monitor air quality in critical environments such as emergency rooms, detecting biological pathogen threats, and would be useful for monitoring respiratory pathogens in mass gatherings. In addition, the cohesive collaboration among mechanical engineering, environmental science and virology will train graduate students with multi- and inter-disciplinary knowledge. Involvement of undergraduate researchers will motivate and better prepare them for pursuit of advanced education. YouTube videos created for this project will be a vehicle to reach the public, for course materials, as well as to promote the interest in utilizing the HERVADS.

This award is being made jointly by two Programs- (1) Instrument Development for Biological Research, in the Division of Biological Infrastructure (Biological Sciences Directorate), and (2) the Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental and Transport Systems (Engineering Directorate).

POR.DRECONTENT:
This DBI-1353423 project aimed to develop a next-generation system that can efficiently collect virus aerosols and detect sampled viruses on-the-spot.  Existing bioaerosol sampling systems are designed for bacterial aerosol collection based on inertia principles. Thus, by default, they are unfortunately very ineffective for capturing virus aerosols because nanometer-sized viruses are much smaller than micron-sized bacteria. As for what occurs during a natural cloud formation process, our novel system utilizes cooling and mixing processes to enlarge an airborne particle’s size through effective water vapor condensation so that the enlarged virus particles can be efficiently separated and collected from air.  Experimental results showed that our new device was able to enlarge 30-nm virus particles to greater than 3-µm particles, and the new system exceeded 90% collection efficiency, an order of magnitude better compared to the less than 10% efficiency of the industry standard device, the BioSampler®. During field sampling for the collection of airborne infectious viruses in a student infirmary, the new system located at least 2 m from seated patients collected a large variety of viable human respiratory viruses during a late-onset outbreak of influenza virus in 2016. Whereas the BioSampler® sometimes also collected virus aerosols, it was nevertheless overall less successful based on a lower frequency of virus isolation in most cases. This side-by-side comparison highlights some limitations of past studies based on conventional sampling approaches, which may have generated false-negative results due to either poor collection efficiency and/or virus inactivation due to the collection process. The significance of virus aerosols in the natural transmission of respiratory diseases has been a contentious issue, primarily because it is difficult to collect/sample virus aerosols using currently available air sampling devices. The results of the student infirmary study using the new virus aerosol collection system indicate that respiratory virus aerosols are more prevalent and potentially pose a greater inhalation biohazard than previously thought.

Conventional detection methods for viruses are time consuming and do not allow determination in field investigation. The paper-based microfluidic device with selective and sensitive detection allows detection of sampled viruses within an hour, orders of magnitude faster than the current method (in days), thus enabling applications even during field investigation. Experimental results with two novel detection methods, NASBA (nucleic acid sequence based amplification) and LAMP (loop-mediated isothermal amplification) for detecting bacteriophage MS2 and flu virus RNAs were demonstrated with the detection limit down to one TCID50 (the amount of a pathogenic virus that will produce pathological changes in 50% of cell cultures inoculated.)

The sampling unit and the paper-based device were integrated using a 3D-printed collector and cassette. The two-layer cassette includes reagent reservoirs and innovative valves for reagent delivery that can be activated by rotating the top layer of the device. Tested with lab generated H1N1 flu virus aerosols, the integrated platform successfully detected the H1N1 viruses with an extremely low amount of 0.8 TCID50.    

The proposed research will have significant societal impacts once the novel device is successfully implemented and widely deployed. It can enable effective sampling and detection of viral aerosols in in a manner not previously attainable.  It will help monitor air quality in critical environments such as emergency rooms, detect biological pathogen threats, and would be useful for monitoring respiratory pathogens in mass gatherings. In addition, the cohesive collaboration among various disciplines has led to graduate students trained with multi- and inter-disciplinary knowledge.  Involvement of undergraduate researchers has motivated and better prepared them for pursuit of advanced education.
